Title: Microfoundations of Collective Defence

The Microfoundations of Collective Defence project seeks to initiate a new research agenda on the fundamental building blocks of collective defence, shedding light on the views of individuals that shape public opinion and inform policy decisions in NATO member states. By integrating experimental political science, international relations, and political psychology approaches, this project will investigate how individuals form attitudes towards allied assistance in different collective defence scenarios, how these attitudes aggregate to form public opinion, and how public opinion influences decision-makers in allied states.

Our research will test three key hypotheses: that strategic context impacts the formation of public opinion, that conventional scenarios of direct armed aggression limit the role of public opinion, and that ambiguous "grey zone" conflicts increase public opinion polarization and relevance for policy-making. To achieve this, we will develop novel immersive mixed-media experiments that provide an interactive, engaging, and realistic experience for participants.

The project's findings have significant policy implications, as they could redefine the stability and credibility of military alliances. By understanding the microfoundations of collective defence, policymakers can better navigate the complexities of alliance politics and make more informed decisions about when and how to provide allied assistance. This research has the potential to inform NATO's strategic decision-making and contribute to a more stable and secure international environment.
